channel.title: Comments on: Honeynet: Linux Security Trends

item.title: By: Pe5kyTac0
item.dc:creator: Pe5kyTac0
item.description: Another reason the Red Hat Linux machine may have taken 3 months to compromise the attackers could have been suspicious that it was a honeypot. If you scan a Linux machine and find that a firewall is up, but ports to all the services are open, it would raise red flags.
item.content:encoded: Another reason the Red Hat Linux machine may have taken 3 months to compromise the attackers could have been suspicious that it was a honeypot. If you scan a Linux machine and find that a firewall is up, but ports to all the services are open, it would raise red flags.

item.title: By: Kint
item.dc:creator: Kint
item.description:
I agree. Also, the metrics to not actually reveal how long the "linux" machines take to compromise (how frequently they were attacked, how long the successful attacks took, etc.). You can sit one vulnerable Fedora box on the net, and observe that it took 3 months before it was compromised. Was your box even noticed before that? It could have been discovered and attacked 2 months and 3 weeks into the run.
Just my 2 cents.
item.content:encoded:
I agree. Also, the metrics to not actually reveal how long the “linux” machines take to compromise (how frequently they were attacked, how long the successful attacks took, etc.). It could have been discovered and attacked 2 months and 3 weeks into the run.

Just my 2 cents.
